results.title: Pop-Up Television Radio Model TR-475U
results.material_description: plastic body with silver metal handle, trim and antenna.
results.brief_description:
National Transistor TV. Model TR-475U. Pop-up screen and pull out handle for portablity.
No power cords, batteries only.

Brand: National

Serial no. F 3 (??) 1113
TQF8125

National Transistor TV
Model TR-475U DC12V 11W
Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd
Made in Japan
TBM 81685

Caution: To prevernt electric shock, do not remove cover. No user-serviceable parts inside, and pilot lamp soldered in place. Refer servicing to qualified service personnel.

Note: Before opening the pop-up portion of this TV. Please release two red screws fixed on the bottom side of the set. These screws are fixed for delivery safety only. The battery enclosed in this TV receiver is disconnected to assure longer life.

Before use, it must be properly connected. Please see instruction manual. For longer battery life: charge more than 10 hours before initial use. After each use once a month.

There are no power cords accompanying the TV.
results.description:
The National Transistor TV Radio Model TR-475U is a battery-operated, portable model features an inbuilt radio and a ‘pop-up’ television screen.
National was a brand used by Panasonic Corporation sell home appliances, personal appliances, and industrial appliances. The National brand operated in Australia until 1988 when it transferred to The Panasonic Corporation.

results.title: National Ranger 505 Transistor TV
results.creator_credit: National Panasonic and Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Panasonic and Matsushita Electrical Co. Ltd.
results.description:
National Ranger 505 Transistor TV is a portable TV with handle, small screen and folding antennae. The television was completely portable - it could be powered with either mains power or batteries, allowing the user to kick back and take the TV to the beach, campground or backyard.

National was a brand used by Panasonic Corporation sell home appliances, personal appliances, and industrial appliances. The National brand operated in Australia until 1988 when it transferred to The Panasonic Corporation.

results.title: Early home consoles
results.brief_description: While the first home console, the Magnavox Odyssey, came out in 1972, it wasn’t the only launched in the decade. Around 1978, the two-player Hanimex TVG-8610C console was released for home use. Featuring detachable joysticks and 10 internally programmed games, it allowed players to customise difficulty levels, automation and keep score. Console like this needed to be run through the home TV to use as a monitor and also required a little domestic diplomacy with family members for a bigger share of screen time.

results.title: TVG-8610C Console
results.brief_description: Console with power cable purchased on ebay February 2020
results.description: The Hanimex TVG-8610C is an early television games console circa 1978. This two-player console has detachable joysticks with 10 internally programmed games (similar to Pong) and allows the player to customise difficulty levels, automation, and keep score.
description_for_label: Console with power cable purchased on ebay February 2020

results.title: Commodore 64 Console and Cassettes
results.brief_description: Consoles and personal computers are common in homes today, but back in 1982 they were pretty rare. Enter the Commodore 64, a wildly popular 8-bit home computer console that was a major contributor to the home computer revolution. With over 17 million units sold worldwide, it was the highest selling single computer at the time and was often used to run educational resources and games. In Australia alone, over 700 games were produced for the Commodore 64. Software was originally released on audio cassette before 5 ¼ inch floppy discs (and later 3½ inch floppy discs) became more common during the 1980s, which we’ve worked to locate, acquire and preserve.

constellations_other.name: Beyond the game industry
constellations_other.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.

results.title: Pair of Commodore C-1342 Joysticks
results.brief_description: Pair of brown Commodore joysticks with red ‘fire’ button compatible with Commodore 64 systems. The user may push in one of eight directions, and a fire button. The control stick is mechanically connected to four switches; up, down, left and right. Pushing the stick in a direction in between two of these ‘cardinal directions’ activates two of the four switches.

results.title: Commodore C2N Datasette
results.brief_description: The Commodore 1530 (C2N) Datasette, later also Datassette (a portmanteau of data and cassette), is Commodore’s dedicated magnetic tape data storage device. Using compact cassettes as the storage medium, it provides inexpensive storage to Commodore’s 8-bit home/personal computers, notably the PET, VIC-20, and C64.

results.title: Commodore 64 Console
results.brief_description:
Commodore 64 Console without joysticks or power cords
Serial Number WGB 28483
results.description:
The Commodore 64 (C64) is an 8-bit home computer console that was in production from 1982-1994. It has been listed as the highest selling single computer model of all time – over 17million units were sold worldwide. The C64 took its name from its 64 kilobytes (65,536 bytes) of RAM. With support for multicolour sprites and a custom chip for waveform generation, the C64 could create superior visuals and audio compared to systems without such custom hardware. Because of this, the C64 was often used as a home gaming console, with accessories such as datasettes and gaming joysticks.
The Commodore 64 holds a unique place in the history of video games. Institutions such as the National Museum of American History and the Science Museum London also hold Commodore 64 consoles in their collections to highlight the impact and significance the C64 had on computing and home video games.
description_for_label:
Commodore 64 Console without joysticks or power cords
Serial Number WGB 28483
